title: Wikiwand - Crystal healing
description: Crystal healing is a pseudoscientific alternative-medicine practice that uses semiprecious stones and crystals such as quartz, agate, amethyst or opal. Adherents of the practice claim that these have healing powers, but there is no scientific basis for this claim. Practitioners of crystal healing believe they can boost low energy, prevent bad energy, release blocked energy, and transform a body's aura.
cleaned_text: Crystal healing Pseudoscientific alternative medicine techniques employs stones and crystals / From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Dear Wikiwand AI, let's keep it short by simply answering these key questions: Can you list the top facts and stats about Crystal healing? Summarize this article for a 10 years old Crystal healing is a [pseudoscientific](/en/Pseudoscience) [alternative-medicine](/en/Alternative-medicine) practice that uses [semiprecious stones](/en/Gemstone) and crystals such as [quartz](/en/Quartz), [agate](/en/Agate), [amethyst](/en/Amethyst) or [opal](/en/Opal). Adherents of the practice claim that these have healing powers, but there is no scientific basis for this claim. [[1]](#cite_note-Regal-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Skepdic-2) [[3]](#cite_note-LS-3) Practitioners of crystal healing believe they can boost low energy, prevent [bad energy](/en/Bad_energy), release blocked energy, and transform a body's [aura](/en/Aura_(paranormal)). [[4]](#cite_note-Christian-4) In one method, the practitioner places crystals on different parts of the body, often corresponding to [chakras](/en/Chakra); or else the practitioner places crystals around the body in an attempt to construct an energy grid, which is purported to surround the client with healing energy. Scientific investigations have found no evidence that such "energy grids" actually exist, and there is no evidence that crystal healing has any greater effect upon the body than any other [placebo](/en/Placebo).
